Reduced morphometric condition index and soft tissue growth rate together with increased lipid peroxidation and low lysosomal membrane stability were also observed at the most contaminated site. column12: Shift in fish assemblage structure due to loss of seagrass Zostera marina habitats in Sweden
column18: four locations in this area, coordinates averaged
column31: number of fish species was found to be significantly higher in Z. marina habitats compared to areas where seagrass was missing. Several species and groups of fishes (i.e., gadoids, labrids, syngnathids) were absent or occurred in low densities at sites where Z. marina was missing. cod density was reduced by 96% at sites where Z. marina had disappeared.

column2: Freitas, C., Olsen, E. M., Knutsen, H., Albretsen, J., & Moland, E. (2015). Temperature?associated habitat selection in a cold?water marine fish. Journal of Animal Ecology, 85(3), 628?637. https://doi.org/10.1111/1365-2656.12458
column4: habitat choice of cod eg seagrass
column7: habitat choice of cod
column12: Temperature-associated habitat selection in a cold-water marine fish
column25: temperature war recorded in the field and cod behavior observed
column26: Significant relationships between ocean temperature and habitat selection and use were found. Under favourable sea temperature thresholds (<16 øC), cod selected vegetated habitats, such as eelgrass and macroalgae beds, available in shallow areas. Selection for those habitats was especially high at night, when cod tended to ascend to shallower areas, presumably to feed. Selection and use of those habitats decreased significantly as temperature rose. Under increased sea surface temperature conditions, cod were absent from vegetated shallow habitats, both during the day and night, and selected instead non-vegetated rocky bottoms and sand habitats, available in deeper, colder areas.

column26: F. evanescens was much less fouled than F. vesiculosus, supporting both less biomass and fewer species of epiphytes. Strong decrease in Fucus biomass over time. Effects of temperature, transparency, bottom type, shoreline orientation and location on the bladderwrack distributions
and depth penetrations at 61 locations across different archipelago zones were measured. Of these, only location indicated a possible effect.

column54:
11 transects were established (1993/1994) revisited in 2000/2001 (Karvonen et al. 2002), and 2006/2007 (this study). 61 diving transects (2006/2007) werestudied including
long-term study transects with 50 new transects. The abundance of F. vesiculosus in the bladderwrack belts decreased significantly from 0.71 to 0.13 between the years
1993 and 2001 and remained low thereafter .

column25: effects of genetic diversity on ecosystem functioning, assessed over 463 days, from June 2011 to September 2012, covering two growth seasons and one winter.
column26:
genetic diversity had no direct effect on shoot densities, it had a stabilizing effect on shoot density. The CV increased with time (P = 0.0001), but polycultures had a consistently lower CV through time (P = 0.027). Although nonsignificant (n=28, P = 0.095), polycultures also tended to have higher plot survival: 91.7% of polyculture
plots survived until September 2012 compared to a 62.5% survival among monoculture plots.

column18: 5 samples from Skagerrak, Baltic proper, Archipelago Sea and Gulf of Finland (x2) were compared with 3 Atlantic samples (France, Ireland, Norway)
column54:
Fst values, neutrality tests: Although no conclusive evidence of selection was detected in neutrality tests, the level of genetic differentiation
based on SNP variation (FST=0.522; but 0.398 and 0.095 for EST-derived and putatively neutral microsatellites,
respectively) is so great that the role of selection is evident. The Bayesian structure analysis supported the view of
great differentiation between marine and brackish populations.

column4: Effect of ocean warming and acidification on fucus (WP2.2)
column7: Effect of ocean warming and acidification on fucus fertility
column12: Seasonal variations of Fucus vesiculosus fertility under ocean acidification and warming in the western Baltic Sea
column25: Temperature and acidification, The effects of future ocean warming were studied by contrasting ambient temperature of Kiel Fjord water with warmer water (+5øC relative to Fjord water) at two pCO2 levels, ambient (ca. 400 ppm) vs. ca. 1100 ppm in the headspace above the Benthocosms.
column26: elevated pCO2 and/or warming do not influence receptacle appearance in autumn, but do accelerate the maturation process during spring, resulting in earlier gamete release and thereby could potentially affect population biomass. In detail: During winter, elevated pCO2 in both ambient and warmed temperatures increased the proportion of mature receptacles significantly. In spring, warming and, to a lesser extent, elevated pCO2 accelerated the maturation of receptacles and advanced the release of gametes by up to 2 weeks.

column2: Svensson, F., Karlsson, E., G†rdmark, A., Olsson, J., Adill, A., Zie, J., ? Ekl”f, J. S. (2017). In situ warming strengthens trophic cascades in a coastal food web. Oikos, 126(8), 1150?1161. https://doi.org/10.1111/oik.03773
column4: Effects of warming on ecosystems (includes filamentous macroalgae, maybe interesting)
column7: In situ warming strengthens trophic cascades in a coastal food web, effects on filamentous algae

column18: two sites inside and two outisde the biotest Basin
column25: Artificially heated Biotest basin (cooling water run off). Since 1980 the basin has received up to ?90 m3 of heated cooling water per second, resulting in a heating of the water by up to 10øC compared to the surroundings at the very entrance of the Biotest basin.
column26: A 45-day cage experiment showed that fish exclusion did not affect the biomass of algal herbivores (gastropods and gammarids), but reduced algal biomass in heated sites (but not unheated). This suggests that warming induced a trophic cascade from fish to algae, and that this effect was mediated by predator-induced changes in herbivore behavior, rather than number.
column31: Algal biomass is higher in heated compared to control sites, The regression analysis using data from each block showed that water temperature positively affected the log response ratio (LRR) of algal biomass in open versus closed cages (LME, t = 4.27, DF = 14, p = 0.0008; Fig. 5). In other words, the strength of the negative effect of fish exclusion on macroalgal biomass increased with increasing water temperature.

column31: Genotyping confirmed the complex genetic structure of the Baltic Sea hybrid zone and revealed an unexpected dominance of M. trossulus alleles being in contrast to the predominance of M. edulis alleles described for wild Baltic blue mussels
column48: The identity of blue mussel populations is therefore important for the farmer to sell certified products and guarantee correct provenance determination to the customer.
column54: DNA obtained from kiel fjord blue mussel specimens was analysed in comparison to DNA from the three pure species of the Me complex, Me (North Sea, Germany), Mg (Adriatic Sea, Croatia) and Mt (North Pacific, Washington, USA) (provided by Senckenberg Natural History Collection of Dresden, Germany). Based on the reference samples, an allele panel was compiled including all alleles and their size ranges detected for Me, Mg and Mt. The constructed allele panel served as the basis for genetic analysis of the 19 mussel individuals. A hybrid score was calculated for each specimen by counting alleles referred to as Me. Thus, hybrid scores ranged from 0 (pure Mt) to 4 (pure Me), whereas a score of 2 is hereafter described as intermediate hybrid. As no alleles specific for Mg were detected in any of the 19 individuals, Mg was not considered for the calculation of the hybrid score.

column54: In total, 24 cages were used. That means that 1 cage represented 1 experimental plot with a unique combination of the 3 experimental factors. In each cage, we placed 3 sampling units for herbivores and 2 units for algae. Thus, replicates were not independent in a full combination of all 3 factors, but rather represented the conditions in each cage. Therefore, we omitted 3-way interactions in the analysis and interpreted interaction effects with great caution (see ?Statistical analysis?).

column54: In total, 24 cages were used. That means that 1 cage represented 1 experimental plot with a unique combination of the 3 experimental factors. In each cage, we placed 3 sampling units for herbivores and 2 units for algae. Thus, replicates were not independent in a full combination of all 3 factors, but rather represented the conditions in each cage. Therefore, we omitted 3-way interactions in the analysis and interpreted interaction effects with great caution (see ?Statistical analysis?).

column31: The beach macroalgae biomass Rgen-Mix represents a possible substrate for use in biogas plants. However, the biomethane recovery rate was shown to be considerably inferior when compared to popular feedstock substrates, such as maize silage or cattle manure. The co-digestion of terrestrial energy crops with 25% seaweed share (by weight) similar to pretreated RM could decrease land-use for bioenergy in Germany by approximately 290,000 hectares for energy crops and approximately 211,000 hectares for maize. This represents 10%?14% of cultivated land where renewable resources are generated for energy use

column4: habitat use: zostera
column7: seegrass as habitat, shapes population dynamics of inhabitants
column12: seagrass habitat structure: A study of life-history traits and population dynamics of Corophium volutator (Pallas)
column31: Seagrass habitat structure affect life-history traits and population dynamics of Corophium volutator. In detail; Corophium volutator was the most abundant organism in the edge of the seagrass meadow and the second most abundant in the inner seagrass meadow. juvenile body length was significantly greater in the patches (Ruppia spp. Zannichellia spp.) than in both seagrass meadows (Zostera marina  Potamogeton pectinatus). The patches supported the lowest animal densities, but were as equally diverse as the seeagrass meadow.

5-20 samples from 13 sites, PCB concentrations in blue mussels depended significantly on the place where the samples were taken (ANOVA F=118.761, p<0.0001). Blue mussels from the area of ferry harbour of Gedser had significantly higher PCB concentrations than those from all other areas (Tukey test: p<0.05). Further, the distance

0.448, ANOVA: F = 32.852, p<0.0001)

column26: biomarkers (catalase, glutathione S-transferase, superoxide dismutase, glutathione reductase, lipid peroxidation, acetylcholinesterase activity and lysosomal membrane stability) Mussels transplanted near the harbor area were able to elevate their antioxidant defense in response to environmental contamination. Reduced morphometric condition index and soft tissue growth rate together with increased lipid peroxidation and low lysosomal membrane stability were also observed at the most contaminated site. The results suggest that caging of M. trossulus for four weeks at lower salinity is a feasible method for the detection of environmental pollution also in low salinity areas of the Baltic Sea.
